content: Hello everyone I'm new to military life, my husband is active duty. We are at our first duty station Ft. Campbell. We have a four year old daughter, we just fought out that we cannot utilize the school or childcare developments because we don't live on base. (First let down)Child is so expensive (100.00 weekly or more). Previous she was in a headstart program back home. I was told no need to apply for supplement to help pay because we make too much (my husband is only E3, but too much I guess, second let down). Help I need someone with new ideas, recommendations, please someone point me in the right direction, if there any hope. I don't want to get a job just to pay childcare. Help..........

title: Stuck in the Middle

content: Please understand that everyone here is pulling for you. I understand where you are coming from, when our oldest daughter was five there was not a pre-school or kindergarten available to us. We had one advantage, my wife never worked outside of the home. We just did without a lot of things, I mean a lot of things. When I was deployed to Vietnam, we could leave our family in quarters. So we moved them to Independence MO and our daughter started school a year late. But it all worked out well for her and us. She is now an E9 in the Coast Guard with 27 years. Their daughters are both college graduates - one just joined the USCG Reserves and the other one is in AF Basic at Lackland AFB. Please keep us posted, so that we can rejoice with you and we may be able to help the nest person who comes our way. Bruce Blessings to you and yours' God and the soldier, All men adore, In time of trouble, And no more; For when war is over, And all things righted, God is neglected - The old soldier slighted. Founding Member Original DVG & Proud Member, Rupterd Duck/Derelict Veterans

content: Santresa, I hope you can get things worked out! Keep smiling, everyone will wonder what you've been up to!

title: Stuck in the Middle

content: When we were military kids, my Mom watched other people's kids, all the time, as she didn't return to work until I was six and my brother was almost four. She always had two or three extra kids every day. She didn't even charge one of the mothers, because she didn't make much money at all. My Mom literally watched this kid for free baked goods. Have you been to any of the Mother's Meetings on base yet? You should start networking, and ask for recommendations for women who watch kids in their own homes, some kind of a set up where they are not just watching TV all day (you run that risk with regular day care too!) There's most likely someone offering in-home care for a more reasonable price than you've been quoted. That's probably your best choice for now.
